title: 112_s622
content: The Act is titled the "Commission on Effective Regulation and Assessment Systems for Public Schools Act." It amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 by adding a new title for the Commission on Effective Regulation and Assessment Systems for Public Schools. The Commission on Effective Regulation and Assessment Systems for Public Schools Act establishes the Commission, defining key terms such as Chairperson and relevant committees. The Commission on Effective Regulation and Assessment Systems for Public Schools Act mandates the establishment of a commission to examine and improve regulatory and assessment requirements in elementary and secondary education to enhance performance and innovation. The Commission on Effective Regulation and Assessment Systems for Public Schools Act establishes a Commission composed of Governors, State legislators, school officers, officials, superintendents, principals, teachers, assessment experts, and effectiveness experts to improve student achievement, teacher performance, and innovation. The Commission on Effective Regulation and Assessment Systems for Public Schools Act establishes a Commission composed of Governors, members of Congress, State legislators, school officials, educators, parents, students, and the general public. The Secretary determines the Commission's membership based on recommendations. A Governor is designated as the Chairperson, and the Commission holds meetings every 6 months, open to the public, with additional meetings as needed. The Commission on Effective Regulation and Assessment Systems for Public Schools Act establishes a Commission with a Chairperson who can schedule meetings as needed. A majority of members form a quorum, and the Commission must hold its first meeting within 60 days of enactment. The Commission on Effective Regulation and Assessment Systems for Public Schools Act grants powers to the Commission, including the ability to schedule meetings as needed. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather testimony, and receive evidence to fulfill its duties. It may invite witnesses from various groups, including teachers, parents, principals, superintendents, and experts. Additionally, the Commission can obtain information from federal agencies. The Commission can directly obtain necessary information from Federal agencies upon request from the Chairperson. SEC. 10004 outlines the duties of the Commission. The Commission shall take necessary actions to understand effective regulation and assessment systems for public schools, focusing on over-regulation, different regulations, compliance costs, and government entities involved. The Commission will analyze compliance costs, identify redundant regulations, and examine interpretations of laws at different government levels. Additionally, they will assess testing and standardized assessments in public schools at the federal, state, and local levels. The Commission will analyze testing and standardized assessment requirements for public schools, including the purpose, frequency, and scheduling of tests, and the time spent on testing by students and teachers. The Commission will analyze standardized assessments, reporting practices, and the quality of test results to improve instruction and evaluate teacher effectiveness. The Commission will analyze standardized assessments to measure student readiness for graduation and college/career readiness without remediation, factors contributing to quality assessments, technology infrastructure needed for next generation assessments, and opportunities to enhance assessment practices for better stakeholder engagement. The Commission will rely on samples of States and local school districts for examples of regulations and testing requirements. They will provide regular reports to the Secretary and relevant committees, including an annual report within one year of the first meeting. The Commission will issue an annual report to the Secretary and relevant committees, analyzing findings and making policy recommendations. The Chairperson will provide testimony to the committees annually. "SEC. 10005. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS." The Commission members serve without compensation, receive travel expenses, and can request assistance from the Assistant Secretary of Elementary and Secondary Education. Federal Government employees can also be detailed to the Commission. Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status and privileges. The table of contents in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include this provision. The Commission on Effective Regulation and Assessment Systems for Public Schools is established with defined powers, duties, and personnel matters.
